Description: Polished grey ware pottery jar, restored from many fragments with numerous areas missing and two portions of modern plaster restoration. Very thin-walled wheel-made vessel with a convex shoulder and slightly pointed base.The exterior is covered by a thin greenish slip which has been polished in horizontal stripes. The neck is totally missisng. It was formerly restored with fragments from a similar vessel, but these have now been removed and are stored with the jar but not attached to it. The fabric of the neck differs from that of the vessel, being more coarse and unpolished.
Curator's comments: This vase is almost certain to have come from the 1886 excavations of Flinders-Petrie for the Egypt Exploration Fund at Tell Dafana. It consists of the fine marl pottery noted by Petrie at this site and the fabric is identical to other pieces known to have come from Tell Dafana.
Bibliographic references: Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.92, fig.6, p.94, p.106, p.194, pl.36, p.217, pl.59)
